article_title: Long VA doctor waits sign of the times?
article_text:
Long VA doctor waits sign of the times?

Photo: Amanda McCoy, MBR In this file photo, patients wait to be seen by a doctor.

Veterans trying to schedule their first visits to VA doctors wait longer in some cities than new patients seeing private physicians, but experts say the government is neither the problem nor the exception in patient access.

article_metadata.description: Veterans trying to schedule their first visits to VA doctors wait longer in some cities than new patients seeing private physicians, but experts say the government is neither the problem nor the exception in patient access.  "The big part of the problem is that we have a more or less infinite demand for medical services and a limited supply of physicians," said Phil Miller, vice president of communications for Merritt Hawkins, an Irving-based physician recruiting firm that has studied waiting times in different cities.  The revelation stunned some lawmakers and prompted a renewed call to build a VA hospital for 29,000 veterans living in 20 counties in the Rio Grande Valley and Coastal Bend.  No one in Texas is known to have died because he or she couldn't get care, but the VA is investigating the death of Vietnam veteran Anson Dale Richardson last year after his doctor tried, but failed, to get him into chemotherapy treatment.  [...] other factors exist as well, including an increasing amount of paperwork that doctors must complete and even lifestyle changes that have revealed a changing landscape for physicians, who often used to work for themselves but now are increasingly employed by corporations.  A Massachusetts Medical Society patient care study of 1,137 physician offices around the state turned up similar results, with the average time to see a family physician down from 45 days in 2012 to 39 days last year.  "While we've achieved success in securing insurance coverage for nearly all of our residents, coverage doesn't guarantee access to care," said Dr. Ronald Dunlap, president of the Massachusetts Medical Society.  Houston's Michael E. DeBakey VA Medical Center has no mental health staffing shortages, but its associate director noted that salary limitations in such areas as orthopedics can hurt recruiting and that finding physicians in rural areas can be difficult.  The average VA patient that we treat is generally older, with multiple chronic conditions and possibly some lifestyle choices, which include smoking and or alcohol and substance abuse, said Weldon, the South Texas VA system director.
article_metadata.author.name: By Sig Christenson
